title: Copilot created a test project in a subdirectory of my current project
body:
Type: Bug I asked copilot to create an mcp server for me. My scenario was an mcp server that could read a binlog and parse it. I asked it if the mcp server was testing and it went through a loop where it was trying to create a .ps1 file to create a .NET project to generate a binlog. It struggled with that and eventually decided to just create a hardcoded test project. That's fine but the location it put the project is not supported. If my mcp.csproj is in my root (where the copilot created it), it cannot create a separate test .csproj in a sub folder. This is because of how C# does globbing you cannot have csproj files in subfolders of other csproj files as you end up with duplicate assembly attributes. It retried a few times by just deleting the various obj folders and I had to step in to ask it to move my main project into a sub folder. Not sure if there's a way to train it when creating a .csproj file to always make sure it's doing that in a peer folder rather than subfolder. title: Copilot was frequently trying to rebuild my mcp server while it was running

labels.name: *out-of-scope
labels.description: Posted issue is not in scope of VS Code

body:
Type: Bug I asked copilot to build me an mcp server in .NET. In the course of doing that, I would ask it to make changes or help me test the mcp server. What I found is that it would immediately jump to making the edit and rebuilding even if the server was still running. In that case, the dll would be locked and the build would fail. It did this about half a dozen times and I caught on and started just stopping the mcp server manually from the mcp.json before letting copilot continue on. It needs some intelligence or training so that it knows to stop the mcp server in my current vscode instance before trying to build. title: Avoid re-sanitizing markdown during rendering
body:
Currently rendering markdown sanitizes the content twice. When creating the output element it also goes: `string -> dom-> string -> dom` (with other hops potentially in the implementation)

This change changes to a single pass that goes `string -> dom` with a single sanitize call. Since we are moving away from DomParser, the output is slightly changed

title: Search and replace across files scrolls poorly
body:
Type: Bug 1. Open a clone of git@github.com:cisagov/thorium.git 2. git fetch origin f2090d7 3. git checkout FETCH_HEAD 4. open the search side panel 5. search for `(//.*\b)ids\b` w/ `Aa`, `_ab_` and `.*` all selected 6. use replace and set the replacement to `$1IDs` 7. use `...` and fill in `files to include` with `*.rs` 8. click on some of the items 9. use the apply all for a file button to advance to the next potentially changeable file ## Actual results you'll see a thing showing x hidden lines and if you're lucky one line, but often zero lines: on advancement, you may see something w/o the lines you're trying to change: sometimes you might not be able to scroll the item into view no matter what: ## Expected results things shouldn't scroll off the top of the screen -- the first replacement should be visible near the top of the pane. title: Hookable undo / redo service
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I'm using Monaco Editor on an enterprise project. I'm essentially using decorations with Monaco as a rich text editor. I'm attempting to make a custom undo / redo stack to handle decorations on top of the default Monaco text edit stack (I have a written a bug report for this on the monaco-editor repository [Undo / Redo does not account for decorations #4949](https://github.com/microsoft/monaco-editor/issues/4949)). I have not heard back on this issue so I'm going through with my own custom implementation basically hooking deltaDecorations to my stack. I have this working with decorations _only_ and have overridden the Ctrl + Z / Ctrl + Y keybinds.

To make this work with text edits, I need to know when elements are being pushed to the undo / redo stack, so I can sync up my stack with Monaco's, and fall through to the default undo / redo handler on simple text edits.

Some potential ways I could see this working -

1. Expose a bindable function that I can call anytime an element gets added to / removed from the stack
2. Some way of peeking into the undo / redo stack

Please let me know if there's any way to do this currently, but from the API I've found there is not much I can use!
Thank you in advance!

title: OAuth PKCE Flow Issue: VS Code Not Sending Client Secret in Token Exchange

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:   1.102.3 (Universal)
- OS Version: 15.6 (24G84) Mac


## Issue Description

VS Code is failing to exchange the authorization code for an access token when using OAuth with PKCE flow for MCP (Model Context Protocol) dynamic client registration. The token exchange request is missing the `client_secret` parameter.

## Expected Behavior

VS Code should successfully exchange the authorization code for an access token using OAuth PKCE flow.

## Actual Behavior

VS Code's OAuth implementation is not including the `client_secret` in the token exchange request, causing the exchange to fail with authentication errors.

## Root Cause Analysis

This creates a contradiction in OAuth flow expectations:

- **PKCE standard (RFC 7636)**: Client secret should **not** be required since PKCE is designed for public clients
- **Current server behavior**: Appears to require `client_secret` even when PKCE parameters are present
- **VS Code implementation**: Correctly omits `client_secret` per PKCE standards

## Technical Context

According to OAuth 2.0 RFC 7636 (PKCE), PKCE was designed to mitigate authorization code interception attacks for public clients

The security is provided by:
1. `code_challenge` (SHA256 hash) sent with authorization request
2. `code_verifier` (original random string) sent with token exchange
3. Server validates that SHA256(code_verifier) == code_challenge

## Questions for Clarification

1. **Should the MCP OAuth server support PKCE without client secrets?**
   - This would align with OAuth 2.0 standards for public clients
   - VS Code as a desktop application fits the public client profile

2. **Is there a configuration option to enable PKCE-only authentication?**
   - Allow token exchange with just `code_verifier` validation
   - Skip `client_secret` requirement when PKCE parameters are present

3. **Should VS Code's MCP implementation be updated to include client secrets?**
   - This would require secure storage of secrets in VS Code
   - May not align with public client security model

## Proposed Solutions

1. **Server-side**: Update OAuth server to accept PKCE-only token exchanges
2. **Client-side**: Modify VS Code MCP extension to include client secret if required
3. **Configuration**: Add server option to toggle PKCE vs secret-based validation


## Additional Context

This issue affects the dynamic client registration flow for MCP servers that use OAuth for authentication, preventing proper integration with VS Code's MCP extension.

title: Support server.json being returned by assisted MCP install
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

This works around the lack of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259100 and is progress on https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257679. There will be a separate PR on the chat extension to support server.json in NuGet packages.

It enhances the `github.copilot.chat.mcp.setup.flow` command to have an additional `type` property. When this type property is set to `"server.json"`, the result is treated as an MCP Registry server.json and mapped to the VS Code configuration format. If the `type` property is falsey set or set to `"vscode"`, the existing codepath is used.

Additionally, I updated the `toScannedMcpServerAndInputs` to be a public static method so it can be called after the `github.copilot.chat.mcp.setup.flow` command returns. 

I noticed the resulting `args` and `env` placeholder values had the format `{input:foo}`, instead of format `${input:foo}`. Based on https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/reference/variables-reference#_input-variables, it seems like this was a bug in the original implementation, but I may be wrong. @sandy081 - could you confirm?

Verified with:
- npm: `@azure/mcp` (old flow, no server.json)
- Python: `mcp-server-fetch` (old flow, no server.json)
- Docker: `mcp/node-code-sandbox` (old flow, no server.json)
- NuGet: `NuGet.Mcp.Server` (new flow), `Knacode.SampleMcpServer` (new flow, this one has an input)

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3 488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81 x64
- OS Version: Windows 11 24H2, Build 26100.4652
- PSVersion                      7.5.2
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Edit Mode
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4
- Logs:

**Bug Description:**
VS Code recreates deleted files as empty files, showing them as "changed" in Git

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Delete multiple PowerShell test files using Remove-Item in terminal
2. Make a Git commit
3. Notice deleted files reappear as empty files marked as "changed"

**Expected Behavior:**
Deleted files should remain deleted and not be recreated

**Actual Behavior:**
Files are recreated as empty files and show up in Git status as modified

**Environment:**
- VS Code Version: [your version]
- GitHub Copilot Extension: [version]
- OS: Windows
- PowerShell: [version]

**Workaround:**
Use `git rm filename` instead of `Remove-Item` and restart VS Code

title: Fix FileOperationError serialization across Extension Host-Renderer boundary
body:
When notebook files are modified externally while code is running, VS Code should show a specific "File modified since" dialog with Overwrite/Revert options. However, due to error serialization issues across the Extension Host-Renderer boundary, users were seeing a generic error dialog instead.

## Problem

The issue occurs when:
1. A notebook cell is executing and updating output
2. The same notebook file is modified in another editor and saved
3. A `FileOperationError` with `FILE_MODIFIED_SINCE` is thrown in the Extension Host
4. The error gets serialized via RPC protocol to cross the process boundary
5. Critical properties (`fileOperationResult` and `options`) are lost during serialization
6. The Renderer receives a generic `Error` instead of a proper `FileOperationError`
7. `storedFileWorkingCopy.ts` cannot detect the specific error type and shows a generic dialog

## Root Cause

The `transformErrorForSerialization` function in `errors.ts` only preserved basic Error properties (`name`, `message`, `stack`, etc.) but not the custom properties that make `FileOperationError` meaningful (`fileOperationResult` and `options`).

## Solution

Extended the error serialization infrastructure to preserve `FileOperationError`-specific properties:

1. **Extended `SerializedError` interface** to include `fileOperationResult` and `fileOperationOptions` fields
2. **Updated `transformErrorForSerialization`** to detect and preserve FileOperationError properties during serialization
3. **Updated `transformErrorFromSerialization`** to reconstruct FileOperationError objects with their semantic properties intact
4. **Updated RPC protocol deserialization** to use proper error transformation instead of raw JSON parsing

## Testing

- Added unit tests for FileOperationError serialization/deserialization
- Added integration test for RPC protocol error handling
- Verified the fix preserves error semantics across process boundaries
- Confirmed backward compatibility with existing error types

The fix is minimal and targeted, ensuring that `FileOperationError` objects maintain their semantic meaning when crossing the Extension Host-Renderer boundary, allowing the correct error dialogs to be displayed to users.

Fixes #259618.

title: feat: upgrade search toggle setting to true
Fix test coverage toolbar quickpick activeItem selection bug
body:
The Test Coverage Toolbar's quickpick was not correctly setting the active entry when reopened after a previous selection. This caused the "All tests" row to always be selected instead of remembering the previously selected test.

## Root Cause

The issue was in the quickpick items array construction where the first item (representing "All tests") used `id: undefined` instead of `testId: undefined`:

```typescript
const items: QuickPickInput<TItem>[] = [
    { label: coverUtils.labels.allTests, id: undefined },  // ❌ Wrong property name
    { type: 'separator' },
    ...tests.map(testId => ({ label: coverUtils.getLabelForItem(result, testId, commonPrefix), testId })),
];
```

This created a type mismatch with the `TItem` type definition (`{ label: string; testId?: TestId }`), causing the `activeItem` finder to fail:

```typescript
activeItem: items.find((item): item is TItem => 'testId' in item && item.testId?.toString() === previousSelectionStr)
```

The type guard `'testId' in item` would return `false` for the "All tests" item because it had an `id` property instead of `testId`, preventing it from being found when it should be the active selection.

## Fix

Changed `id: undefined` to `testId: undefined` to match the expected type structure:

```typescript
const items: QuickPickInput<TItem>[] = [
    { label: coverUtils.labels.allTests, testId: undefined },  // ✅ Correct property name
    { type: 'separator' },
    ...tests.map(testId => ({ label: coverUtils.getLabelForItem(result, testId, commonPrefix), testId })),
];
```

Now the activeItem finder correctly identifies both "All tests" selections (when `previousSelection` is `undefined`) and specific test selections.

Fixes #259606.

title: Add extension source information support to EditSources.applyEdits
body:
The `EditSources.applyEdits()` method was the only edit source that didn't support tracking extension information, unlike other methods like `suggest` and `codeAction` which include provider details for telemetry and debugging.

## Changes

Modified `EditSources.applyEdits` to accept an optional parameter containing `providerId` information:

```typescript
// Before
applyEdits: () => createEditSource({ source: 'applyEdits' } as const)

// After  
applyEdits: (data?: { providerId?: ProviderId | undefined }) => createEditSource({ 
  source: 'applyEdits', 
  ...toProperties(data?.providerId) 
} as const)
```

When a `ProviderId` is provided, the edit source now includes:
- `$extensionId`: Extension identifier
- `$extensionVersion`: Extension version
- `$providerId`: Provider identifier within the extension

## Backward Compatibility

Existing code continues to work unchanged:
```typescript
// This still works exactly as before
const editSource = EditSources.applyEdits();
```

## Usage

The change enables better tracking when extensions perform bulk edits:

```typescript
const providerId = new ProviderId('my.extension', '1.0.0', 'myProvider');
const editSource = EditSources.applyEdits({ providerId });
// Now includes extension information for telemetry/debugging
```

This follows the established pattern used by other `EditSources` methods and provides the infrastructure for improved edit source tracking in the bulk edit pipeline.

Fixes #259611.

title: Support dragging terminal tab out to create new terminal window
body:
This PR implements the ability to drag terminal tabs outside of VS Code to automatically create new editor windows containing those terminals.

## How it works

When a user drags a terminal tab and moves it outside the VS Code application boundary, the system detects this and automatically moves the terminal to a new editor window using the existing `moveIntoNewEditor()` functionality.

## Implementation details

The feature is implemented by enhancing two existing drag-and-drop classes:

- **`SingleTerminalTabActionViewItem`**: Handles dragging individual terminal tabs from the terminal view
- **`TerminalTabsDragAndDrop`**: Handles dragging multiple terminal tabs from the terminal tabs list

### Detection mechanism

1. When a drag starts, the system tracks the dragged terminal(s)
2. Document-level `dragleave` events are monitored for `relatedTarget === null`, which indicates the drag has left the application
3. A 100ms timeout prevents false positives when dragging over child elements within VS Code
4. If the timeout expires without the drag returning, the terminal is moved to a new editor window

### Integration with existing code

The implementation leverages VS Code's existing infrastructure:
- Uses the existing `moveIntoNewEditor()` method from `ITerminalService`
- Follows established drag-and-drop patterns with `TerminalDataTransfers`
- Integrates with the disposal system to prevent memory leaks
- Maintains consistency with VS Code's TypeScript patterns

## User experience

Users can now drag terminal tabs outside VS Code to create new windows, similar to how browser tabs work. The terminal maintains its state and continues running in the new window, providing a natural way to organize terminals across multiple windows.

Fixes #259604.

title: Fix GitHub PR review headers showing redundant URL prefixes
body:
This change fixes an issue where GitHub PR review comment headers in VS Code displayed redundant URL content that doesn't appear on the actual GitHub.com website.

**Problem:**
When viewing GitHub PR reviews in VS Code, comment thread headers were showing URL prefixes like:
```
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/123 Fix header issue
```

However, on GitHub.com, the same headers display cleanly without the URL prefix:
```
Fix header issue
```

**Solution:**
Added a `removeUrlPrefix()` method to the `CommentThreadHeader` class that strips URL prefixes from comment thread labels before displaying them. The method uses a regex pattern `/^\s*https?:\/\/[^\s]+\s*/` to match and remove:
- HTTP/HTTPS URLs at the beginning of labels
- Leading whitespace before URLs
- Trailing whitespace after URLs

**Example transformation:**
- Before: `"https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/123 Fix header issue"`
- After: `"Fix header issue"`

The fix is applied in the `createThreadLabel()` method where comment thread labels are processed for display, ensuring all GitHub PR review headers appear clean and consistent with the GitHub.com experience.

Fixes microsoft/vscode-pull-request-github#7509.

title: Fix Python completions persisting after exiting REPL with quit()
body:
Python completions were incorrectly persisting in the terminal after exiting a Python REPL with `quit()`. The issue occurred because the LSP completion provider was not validating the current shell type before providing completions.

## Problem
After following these steps:
1. Open Python REPL in terminal
2. Confirm Python completions work (e.g., typing "a" shows `abs`, `all`, `any`, etc.)
3. Run `quit()` to exit Python REPL
4. Try to trigger completions again

**Bug**: Users would still see Python completions instead of normal terminal completions, as shown in the attached screenshot.

## Root Cause
The `LspCompletionProviderAddon.provideCompletions()` method was not checking whether the current shell type was still Python before returning Python completions. Even after the shell type changed back to a regular shell (bash, zsh, etc.), the LSP provider would continue serving Python completions when called.

## Solution
This PR implements a defense-in-depth approach:

### 1. Shell Type Validation in Completion Provider
Added an early return in `LspCompletionProviderAddon.provideCompletions()` that checks if the current shell type is Python before providing any completions:

```typescript
// Early return if the shell type is no longer Python
if (this._lspTerminalModelContentProvider.shellType !== GeneralShellType.Python) {
    return undefined;
}
```

### 2. Enhanced Shell Type Change Handling
- Added a public `shellType` getter to `LspTerminalModelContentProvider` for better encapsulation
- Enhanced `shellTypeChanged()` to clear the virtual document content when transitioning away from Python, preventing stale Python context from persisting

### 3. Comprehensive Test Coverage
Added thorough tests covering:
- Completions provided only when shell type is Python
- No completions when shell type is not Python or undefined
- Proper behavior during shell type transitions
- Virtual document cleanup when leaving Python shell

## Integration
This fix works alongside the existing addon disposal logic in `TerminalSuggestContribution` that calls `this._lspAddon.clear()` when shell type changes. The shell type validation provides an additional safety layer to handle any potential race conditions or timing issues.

## Verification
- ✅ Manual testing confirms Python completions no longer persist after `quit()`
- ✅ Normal Python REPL functionality remains unchanged
- ✅ Comprehensive test suite covering all transition scenarios
- ✅ Minimal, surgical changes with no breaking modifications

Fixes #258682.

title: Fix Tree Quick Pick sticky scroll background color mismatch
body:
The Tree Quick Pick sticky scroll background color was not matching the tree background color in the tools picker, causing a visual inconsistency in the Dark Modern theme (and potentially other themes).

![Tree Quick Pick with mismatched sticky scroll background](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a9deeb35-6351-4eb6-a30f-2974cd938aca)

**Root Cause:**
The issue occurred because:
1. `treeStickyScrollBackground` was undefined in the default list styles
2. The quick input service was setting `listBackground` but not `treeStickyScrollBackground` 
3. The tree component was not receiving the same styling as the list component

**Solution:**
- Added `treeStickyScrollBackground: quickInputBackground` to the list styles override in `quickInputService.ts`
- Added `this.ui.tree.tree.style(this.styles.list)` to ensure the tree receives proper styling in `quickInputController.ts`

This ensures that both the tree background and sticky scroll background use the same `quickInputBackground` color, maintaining visual consistency. The fix follows the `overrideStyles` approach suggested in the issue comments and applies to all tree quick pick dialogs, including the "Configure Tools" picker shown in the screenshot.

Fixes #259578.

title: Add "Stop Editing All Cells" command for notebooks
body:
This PR adds a new command that allows users to stop editing all currently editable cells in a notebook simultaneously, addressing a common workflow pain point.

## Problem
Users working with notebooks containing multiple markdown cells in editing mode had to manually stop editing each cell individually by:
- Pressing Escape while focused on each cell
- Clicking outside each cell  
- Using the existing "Stop Editing Cell" command for each cell

This was particularly tedious for documentation-heavy notebooks with many markdown cells.

## Solution
Added a new **"Stop Editing All Cells"** command (`notebook.quitEditAllCells`) that:
- Finds all markdown cells currently in editing state
- Updates them to preview state using the existing `updateEditState()` API
- Ignores code cells (which don't have edit states like markdown cells)
- Ignores cells already in preview mode

## Usage
- **Command Palette**: F1 → "Stop Editing All Cells"
- **Keybinding**: `Ctrl+Escape` (Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+Escape` (macOS)
- **Context**: Available when notebook editor is focused and editable

## Implementation Details
- Extends `NotebookAction` for notebook-level operations
- Uses `viewModel.viewCells.filter()` to identify editing cells
- Follows established patterns from similar commands like `ClearAllCellOutputsAction`
- Proper error handling and context validation
- Minimal code changes (~48 lines in single file)

## Demo
**Before**: Multiple cells in editing state requiring individual attention
![Before](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/701cb431-8bbf-4524-9654-d1cba9277a26)

**After**: All editing cells switched to preview state with single command
![After](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/02a0ad84-d461-4931-bdd2-2a1a6da2d05f)

The demo shows the command successfully identifying and updating 3 markdown cells from editing to preview state while properly ignoring code cells.

Fixes #258908.

title: Disable indent guides in Quick Pick trees to reduce visual noise
body:
Quick Pick trees (used for the Tools picker and other hierarchical selection interfaces) were displaying indent guides by default, which added visual noise and reduced readability. The vertical lines created unnecessary clutter in the tree interface, making it harder to focus on the actual content.

This change disables indent guides specifically for Quick Pick trees by setting `renderIndentGuides: RenderIndentGuides.None` in the tree configuration. The fix:

1. Imports `RenderIndentGuides` from the abstractTree module
2. Adds the `renderIndentGuides: RenderIndentGuides.None` option to the QuickInputTreeController tree configuration

This aligns the Quick Pick tree behavior with the existing Quick Pick list implementation, which already disables indent guides for the same reason. The change is minimal and surgical, affecting only the visual presentation without impacting any functionality.

**Before:** Tree shows distracting vertical indent guide lines
**After:** Clean tree interface without visual noise from indent guides

Fixes #259579.

title: Error When Building VSCode from Source on Windows with Visual Studio Installed in a Custom Path

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Issues identified as good for first-time contributors

labels.name: author-verification-requested
labels.description: Issues potentially verifiable by issue author

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0
- OS Version: Windows 11 23H2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Visual Studio in custom path rather than default
2. run `npm install`
3. error occur
```
> code-oss-dev@1.104.0 preinstall
> node build/npm/preinstall.js

*** Invalid C/C++ Compiler Toolchain. Please check https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#prerequisites.
path\to\vscode\build\npm\preinstall.js:31
                throw new Error();
                ^
```
## Troubleshooting:
```javascript
// build/npm/preinstall.js
if (process.platform === 'win32') {
	if (!hasSupportedVisualStudioVersion()) {
		console.error('\x1b[1;31m*** Invalid C/C++ Compiler Toolchain. Please check https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#prerequisites.\x1b[0;0m');
		throw new Error();
	}
	installHeaders();
}

if (process.arch !== os.arch()) {
	console.error(`\x1b[1;31m*** ARCHITECTURE MISMATCH: The node.js process is ${process.arch}, but your OS architecture is ${os.arch()}. ***\x1b[0;0m`);
	console.error(`\x1b[1;31m*** This can greatly increase the build time of vs code. ***\x1b[0;0m`);
}

function hasSupportedVisualStudioVersion() {
	const fs = require('fs');
	const path = require('path');
	// Translated over from
	// https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:build/vs_toolchain.py;l=140-175
	const supportedVersions = ['2022', '2019', '2017'];

	const availableVersions = [];
	for (const version of supportedVersions) {
		let vsPath = process.env[`vs${version}_install`];
		if (vsPath && fs.existsSync(vsPath)) {
			availableVersions.push(version);
			break;
		}
		const programFiles86Path = process.env['ProgramFiles(x86)'];
		const programFiles64Path = process.env['ProgramFiles'];

		const vsTypes = ['Enterprise', 'Professional', 'Community', 'Preview', 'BuildTools', 'IntPreview'];
		if (programFiles64Path) {
			vsPath = `${programFiles64Path}/Microsoft Visual Studio/${version}`;
			if (vsTypes.some(vsType => fs.existsSync(path.join(vsPath, vsType)))) {
				availableVersions.push(version);
				break;
			}
		}

		if (programFiles86Path) {
			vsPath = `${programFiles86Path}/Microsoft Visual Studio/${version}`;
			if (vsTypes.some(vsType => fs.existsSync(path.join(vsPath, vsType)))) {
				availableVersions.push(version);
				break;
			}
		}
	}
	return availableVersions.length;
}
```
When `preinstall.js` checks for VisualStudioVersion, it only looks for Visual Studio in the default installation path—this is why the error is thrown when Visual Studio is installed in a custom location.

## Temporary solution:
Set the `vs${version}_install` environment variable before running `npm install`.

## suggestions:
1. Refer to how the node-gyp project [find Visual Studio](https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/blob/main/lib/find-visualstudio.js)
2. Detailed error description (If you installed Visual Studio to a custom path, you can specify it via the `vs${version}_install` environment variable)
3. Maybe we can remove this piece of code? It seems that the check here is useless for now.

title: fix: update capitalization for 'Restore to Last Checkpoint' hover text
body:
#259566 

This PR updates the hover text for the Restore to Last Checkpoint action to follow the project's capitalization guidelines. Specifically, it ensures that all major words are capitalized, except for short words like "to", in line with the style rules.

Changes

Updated hover label from Restore to last checkpoint → Restore to Last Checkpoint.

Rationale
The existing hover text did not follow the UI capitalization conventions used in the project. This change improves consistency and adheres to the design and style guidelines.

Before
Restore to last checkpoint

After
Restore to Last Checkpoint

title: Chinese IME cursor jumps incorrectly when typing numbers matching selected text

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: editor-input-IME
labels.description: Editor input of characters not on keyboard

body:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: Windows 10 22H2

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Enable `editor.editContext: true` (default since 1.101)
2. Switch to Microsoft Traditional Chinese IME
3. Create new file, type `1000` and save
4. Select the text `1000`
5. Press number key `1` on numeric keypad (same as first digit of selected text)
6. Expected: `1000` should be replaced with `1`
7. Actual: Cursor jumps to end of selection, nothing is typed

**Also occurs with:**
- Select `2000`, press `2` → same issue
- Select `3000`, press `3` → same issue
- And so on

**Additional Info:**
- Issue started in v1.101 when EditContext became default
- v1.100 works correctly (EditContext was experimental)
- Workaround: Set `editor.editContext: false`
